Graphical abstract The removal of phenol from aqueous industrial effluents by catalytic wet-air oxidation (CWAO) is a challenging process that requires novel catalysts resistant to leaching of the active phases during residence time in a batch reactor. In this sense, this work demonstrated that this can be archived with the catalyst having the spinel phase Co3O4 supported on mesoporous silica SBA-15 doped with an optimized amount of TiO2 (3 wt%). In the phenol CWAO reaction carried out at 160 °C and 10 bar O2, this best Co3O4/TiO2/SBA-15 catalyst showed an increase of phenol conversion from 49.0 % to 68.3 % and of CO2 selectivity from 87 % to 98 %. The extensive catalyst characterization and overall activity results indicated that this was related to the strength and nature of the acid sites and the oxidation states of the cobalt oxide phases. Combined factors influenced the final behaviour of the catalyst, such as its intrinsic activity, dispersion of the active phase, inhibition of CoSiO4 phase formation, high Lewis acidity and the large amount of active Co3O4 spinel phase. The presence of TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) decorating the support surface improved the stability of the catalyst by inhibiting the leaching of cobalt species during the reaction. After three reaction cycles, the most efficient Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst showed high CO2 selectivity (∼92.7 %) and low selectivity towards carboxylic acid (∼5.3 %) and polyphenolic compounds (∼2%). It is proposed that surface oxidation is the rate-determining step in the CWAO reaction over TiO2/SBA-15-supported Co3O4 spinel catalysts. Keywords CWAO Wastewater treatment Phenol degradation spinel Co3O4 catalysts SBA-15 TiO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Phenol is used in various industrial processes such as chemical, petrochemical and pharmaceutical manufacturing. Unfortunately, it is also one of the most toxic substances that damage aquatic life, pollute water sources and cause serious health problems in humans [1,2]. In this regard, there are strict environmental regulations that drastically limit the level of phenol in wastewater [3]. To comply with these regulations, there are numerous technologies for phenol removal from wastewater such as biological treatment, chemical oxidation, adsorption, membrane filtration and catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) [4,5]. Among them, catalytic wet oxidation of phenol is one of the most effective methods. This method consists of catalytic oxidation of an aqueous solution of organic pollutant by dissolved molecular oxygen under mild temperature and moderate oxygen or air pressure [6,7] . Although this is one of the most effective methods, total phenol removal is challenging due to the low reactivity of phenol and the formation of intermediate compounds (e.g., plastics) that can block the active sites of the catalyst [8] . When the CWAO reaction is carried out in a batch reactor, the catalytic oxidation of phenol can be performed using homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts [8] . Although homogeneous catalysts such as Cu, Fe, Ni Co and Mn exhibit high activity and selectivity, they are difficult to recover and easy to drain. Compared to these catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts have the advantage of being easily recoverable and reusable, but their active component can be easily leached [9] . Thus, the challenge is to improve their stability. For heterogeneous catalysts, the concentration of active oxygen species at the catalyst active sites is the crucial factor influencing the CWAO performance [10]. In this regard, noble metals such as Ru, Rh, Pd, and Pt (loadings < 5 %) supported on substrates like γ-Al2O3, TiO2, CeO2, ZrO2, and carbon-based materials have been shown to exhibit superior catalytic activity and enhanced resistance to metal leaching during CWAO than non-noble metal catalysts [6,9]. [11,12]. However, the latter catalysts are considered a cost-effective alternative for the catalytic oxidation of phenol in wet air, even though they exhibit somewhat lower catalytic performance than noble metal catalysts [9,13] . Among the non-noble metal catalysts, those based on cobalt oxide are of special interest because their Co-O bonds can be easily broken to obtain oxygen, which is subsequently used in the oxidation process [6,9]. For example, the Co3O4 phase was reported to be effective in oxygen evolution reactions (OER) [14,15] . This phase is also well suited for the CWAO reaction because the Co2+/Co3+ redox ion pairs of the Co3O4 spinel phase can promote the formation of reactive oxygen species that facilitate the removal of phenol by catalytic wet oxidation with air [15,16] . In this regard, the reaction kinetics modeling of CWAO of aniline over Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst by Ersoäz, and Atalay [17,18] demonstrated that the reaction takes place through alternative oxidation and reduction of the catalyst surface, being the surface oxidation caused by molecular oxygen adsorbed dissociatively from the gas phase. The liquid phase phenol degradation via CWAO reaction presents many unresolved issues mainly related to the stability of the active phase on the support surface. To address the issue of possible cobalt leaching during the CWAO process, the use of silicon oxide-based supports has been proposed as a potential solution [13,19,20]. This strategy focuses on improving the metal-support interaction, enabling more effective metal dispersion, and significantly decreasing cobalt leaching [19] . Among different support materials, the use of mesoporous silica material such as SBA-15 to support Co catalysts would be promising due to its large surface area (>850 m2/g) that allows high loading of cobalt oxide species. In addition, the ordered mesoporous structure of SBA-15 with hexagonal pores in a 2D matrix and long 1D channels (p6mm plane group) [21] might to facilitate phenol adsorption on the active sites. Because of the low solubility of oxygen in water, the rate of transfer of O2 from the gas phase toward the catalyst has a decisive impact on the phenol oxidation process [22]. In this regard, easier oxygen transfer after modification of SBA-15 silica with TiO2 was demonstrated for a variety of selective and total oxidation reactions [23,24]. Titania incorporation into SBA-15 is usually archived by a direct synthesis method (one-pot synthesis) or by post-synthesis grafting procedure [21] . The post-synthesis grafting was found to be more effective for catalyst activity in the CWAO reaction than one-pot synthesis because leads to creation of well dispersed and isolated Ti-species having oxygen-vacancy sites [23]. Interestingly, the presence of Ti nanoparticles (NPs) on the support surface was found to have an impact on the nature of oxidized intermediates generated during total phenol oxidation [23]. However, the final effect of silica modification with Ti strongly depends on its incorporation methodology and the amount of incorporated Ti, being the pore structure, surface area, wall thickness and catalyst acidity the most affected parameters [25]. The changes of the acid-base catalyst properties might affect the whole CWAO process, as it was demonstrated for CeO2-TiO2 supported Ru and Pt catalysts by Duprez and co-workers [26] . For those catalysts, it was found that an adequate Lewis acidity could be preferable for a high oxygen catalyst storage capacity whereas an increasing of the redox properties may have an adverse effect on their catalytic behavior [26] . This work is a continuation of our previous study on the degradation of phenol by the CWAO reaction over the Co/SBA-15 catalyst in which the pores of SBA-15 were expanded by the introduction of 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (a “blowing agent”) [20]. Since the literature review reveals that there is no study on the CWAO of phenol on spinel Co3O4 catalysts supported on mesoporous TiO2/SBA-15 materials, this prompted us to study whether it would be possible to further improve the activity and stability of the catalyst without pore expansion by modifying the support with TiO2. In this sense, the originality of the present work consists in showing quantitatively the effect of TiO2 on phenol oxidation, focusing our interest on the changes induced by TiO2 on the physicochemical properties of the catalyst, which have been extensively studied by different techniques. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of SBA-15 SBA-15 substrate was prepared via nonionic supramolecular self-assembly between the ethylene oxide/propylene oxide copolymer plate (Pluronic P123) (98,8 % Sigma Aldrich) as the structure template and tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 99 % Sigma Aldrich) as the silicon source. In the synthesis process, 4.0 g of Pluronic 123 (P123) was dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water (deionized, Sigma Aldrich) at room temperature, followed by the addition of 120 mL of 0.5 M HNO3 (65.0–67.0 %, Sigma Aldrich). Then, the solution was heated to 35 °C and stirred for 2 h, after which 3.0 g of 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB; [-C6H2(CH3)2–4-NH2]2 (98 %, Sigma Aldrich) was added, maintaining agitation for another 2 h. Next, 8.5 g of TEOS was added and the mixture was stirred vigorously for one minute before being left under moderate agitation for 24 h. The solution was then placed in an oven at 80 °C for 72 h for hydrothermal treatment. Finally, the obtained solid was washed thoroughly with water until a neutral pH was reached, dried at 80 °C for one hour, and calcined at 500 °C for 6 h (with a ramp of 2 °C/min) to remove the copolymer. The SBA-15 support has been named hereafter as S15. 2.2 Post-Synthesis grafting of SBA-15 with titania Doping of SBA-15 with varying amounts of TiO2 (1, 3 and 5 wt%) was performed by incipient wet impregnation of the synthesized SBA-15 material using of titanium(IV) butoxide (Ti(OBu)4, 97 % Sigma Aldrich) as the titanium source. 1 g of unmodified SBA-15 was treated with a solution containing 0.04, 0.13 and 0.22 g Ti(OBu)4 (to obtain 1, 3 and 5 wt% TiO2, respectively) dissolved in 1.1 mL of 2-propanol (98 wt% purity, Sigma Aldrich). The samples were first dried at room temperature and then at 120 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, they were calcined at 500 °C for 4 h, using a temperature ramp of 2 °C/min. The TiO2/SBA-15 samples will be named in the following as xTi/S15, where x is the nominal TiO2 loading (1, 3 and 5 wt%). 2.3 Synthesis of Co3O4/TiO2/SBA-15 catalysts Co3O4 /TiO2/SBA-15 catalysts were prepared via incipient wet impregnation of the corresponding xTi/S15 supports with a solution containing the required amount (0.72 g) of the cobalt precursor Co(NO3)2(H2O)6 (98 %, Sigma Aldrich) to reach a Co3O4 loading of 20 wt%. The samples were initially dried at room temperature, followed by drying at 120 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, they were calcined at 350 °C for 6 h, using a temperature ramp of 2 °C/min. The calcined samples have been labeled hereafter as Co/xTi/S15, where x is the nominal TiO2 loading of 1, 3 and 5 wt%. 2.4 Characterization techniques The elemental composition of pure supports and calcined catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) on a Perkin Elmer Optima 3300DV apparatus. Prior to analysis, solid samples were digested in a mixture of HF, HCl and HNO3. The number of surface active cobalt sites was determined by CO pulse chemisorption in ChemBET Pulsar™ TPR/TPD apparatus. For the calculation of dispersion, it was assumed that each surface cobalt atom can to adsorb a single molecule of CO. The crystallographic properties of the synthesized materials were determined by low and wide angle powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a PANalytical Aeris diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å). Wide-angle X-ray diffraction pattern were performed in the range 10–80 ° with a scan rate of 0.021°/min. Textural properties of the supports and calcined catalysts were determined from N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196 °C using a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 apparatus with all samples degassed at 200 °C for 10 h prior to analysis. The surface morphology of the prepared catalysts was investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (a Hitachi TM-1000 instrument) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). TEM studies were performed on a JOEL 2010 emission field microscope equipped with a polar piece of ultra-high resolution (spherical aberration coefficient Cs = 0.5 mm) operating at 200 kV. For the analysis, the solid samples were dispersed in a solution with water and n-propanol, the drops of the supernatant liquid were placed in holey grids of copper and carbon (300 mesh). The electronic properties of the calcined catalysts were investigated by ultraviolet–visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS UV–vis) using an Agilent Cary-5000 UV–Vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. The bandgap energy values of the synthesized supports and calcined catalysts were evaluated using the Kubelka-Munk plot. Prior to analysis, the samples used were pretreated with Ar for 1 h and then the spectra were collected. The redox properties of the calcined catalysts were studied by temperature programmed reduction with H2 (TPR-H2) carried out in a homemade system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Prior to the TPR characterizations, 30 mg of sample was degassed at 150 °C in N2 flow for 1 h, cooled to room temperature, then the flow was changed to 25 mL·min−1 of 10 %H2/Ar mixing gas, followed by TPR measurements, at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. The surface chemical properties of the calcined catalysts were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a SPECS® spectrometer equipped with a PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer (angular resolution < 0.5°), an XR 50 X-ray source and a μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray monochromator (Al excitation line). Samples were first placed on a stainless steel holder mounted on a sample rod in the spectrometer pretreatment chamber and then degassed at 150 °C for 1 h before transfer to the analysis chamber. Charge effects were corrected by taking the binding energies (BE) of the C 1 s peak of the adventitious carbon at 284.5 eV. Peak analyses were performed with software provided by VG and using the nonlinear least squares fitting program. The nature of the acid sites and their strength were evaluated by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine at different temperatures using an Agilent 660 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with an ISRI transmission heated cell and an in situ high-low pressure infrared reactor with CaF2 windows. Our equipment is configured for tropical conditions, featuring Thallium Bromoiodide-based optics, a detector, and windows. The self-supporting wafers of the catalysts, with a thickness of 60 mg cm−2, were prepared by pressing the powdered samples at a pressure of 8 x 103 kg·cm−2 for 20 min. Prior to the experiments, the self-supporting wafers were flushed with nitrogen gas (60 cm3 min−1), gradually increasing temperature up to 300 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C·min−1, and held at this temperature for 3 h. After cooling the sample to 100 °C under nitrogen flow and degassing under vacuum (10-5 mbar) for 1 h, the sample was exposed to 5 mbar pyridine (98 %, Sigma Aldrich) for 30 min. IR spectra corresponding to the adsorption of pyridine at temperatures of 200, 300, 400 and 500 °C were collected in the same manner after evacuating the physically adsorbed pyridine (10-5 Torr) for 30 min. To quantify the concentrations of both types of acid sites, pyridine adsorption was carried out at 100 °C and a partial pressure of 5 mbar for 30 min, followed by desorption for 10 min at the same temperature. The concentration of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was determined from the integral areas of the absorption bands at 1543 and 1450 cm−1, respectively, using the molar absorption coefficients reported by Emeis [27] for the Brønsted (1.67 cm·μmol−1) and Lewis (2.22 cm·μmol−1) acid-sites. The amount of coke in the spent catalysts was determined by its combustion using a TGA/SDTA851 thermogravimetric apparatus (Mettler Toledo). Prior to analysis, hydrocarbons, adsorbed gases and water were removed from the catalyst surface by degassing at 500 °C under an ultrahigh purity Ar flow (99.9 %, Infra) for 1 h. After cooling the sample to room temperature, the coke was burned using a gaseous mixture of 20 % O2/N2 (Infra) and raising the temperature to 1150 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1. 2.5 Catalytic activity Catalyst activity was evaluated in the reaction of phenol catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) at 160 °C and 10 bar total pressure using pure oxygen (Liquid Air) as the oxidizing agent. Prior to activity testing, a series of experiments were performed varying particle sizes (0.2, 0.4 and 0.6 mm) and stirring speed (350–500-700 rpm) to confirm that there were no mass transfer limitations. To ensure that the CWAO reaction occurs predominantly in the kinetic regime, selectivity was compared at relatively low phenol conversions (approximately 30 %) and initial reaction rates were calculated. Weisz parameters < 0.4 (in dimensionless units) confirmed the absence of diffusion problems. The CWAO reaction was carried out in a 500 mL stainless steel high-pressure batch reactor (a Parr Instruments model 4562HT). Prior to the catalyst loading into reactor, the calcined catalyst (200 mg, 200 mesh) was dried at 150 °C under N2 flow (99.9 %) for 2 h. The feed consisted of 200 mL of an aqueous phenol solution having concentration of 500 ppm of phenol (99 %, Sigma Aldrich). Prior to the catalytic reaction, ambient air was displaced by introducing high purity nitrogen (99.9 %, Infra) and then the temperature was increased to 160 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min while maintaining constant stirring at 800 rpm. Once thermal stability was reached, the reactor was pressurized with oxygen (99.5 %, Infra) to a total pressure of 10 bar. The reaction conditions employed (160 °C and 10 bar of total pressure) were similar to that employed in literature [28–33]. At specific intervals during the reaction, aliquots were periodically extracted and the solid catalysts were separated using filtration. We added 10 μL of acetophenone as an internal standard to each filtered sample. These were then analysed using a GC (Agilent 7890) equipped with a FID detector and an Agilent VF-1 ms column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 µm). The temperatures for the injector, detector, and oven were set at 220 °C, 280 °C, and 180 °C, respectively. To confirm the identity of the reaction products, we injected samples of known oxidation products. We then compared their retention times to those of the reaction products for verification. Carboxylic acids were detected via HPLC (Agilent 1100) using a C18 reverse phase column. The mobile phase comprised methanol and ultra-pure water in a 35:65 (v/v) ratio, with a flow rate of 1 mL/min, and detection was at 254 nm using a diode array detector. Both HPLC grade methanol and ultra-pure water from a Millipore Direct-Q system were used to prepare the mobile phase. This method enabled qualitative identification of intermediates by comparing retention times with those of known pure compounds in the analysed liquid samples. To establish a mass balance and determine the selectivity towards complete combustion (through CO2 formation), total carbon compound analysis measurements were performed. Total carbon content was determined with a Shimadzu analyser (TOC 5000 model). For all catalysts, phenol conversion and total organic carbon (TOC) conversion were calculated using equations (1) and (2), respectively. (1) X phenol = C 0 - C i C 0 where C0 represents the initial phenol concentration, while Ci denotes the phenol concentration at a given time. (2) TOC = TOC 0 - T O C i TOC 0 ∗ 100 where TOC0 represents the initial total concentration of organic carbon compounds, while TOCi refers to the concentration of organic carbon compounds at the end of the catalytic test. Taking into account the formation of CO2, the selectivity towards to CO 2 was calculated using by the following equation: (3) S CO 2 = X TOC C i The initial reaction rate (r 0) per unit mass of catalyst (mmol·h−1·gcat -1) was calculated using the TOC conversion values (equation (4)) and assuming a pseudo-first-order kinetic model. (4) r 0 = Δ T O C % / Δ t / C 0 × m cat were (ΔTOC(%)/Δt) is an initial slope of the TOC values as a function of the time curves; [C0] is the initial phenol concentration and m cat is the mass of catalyst (gcat -1· L-1). The turnover frequency (TOF) was subsequently calculated by normalizing this initial rate to the estimated number of surface active cobalt sites. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports and catalysts It is well known that the exact PZC value of the SBA-15 support (pure SiO2) depends not only on the chemical nature of the support, but also on its history and the method by which it was manufactured. The point of zero charge (PZC) of SBA-15 is remarkably low (approx. 3), so that at inappropriate pH values the support itself may dissolved. The addition of titanium oxide (PZC ca. 5.8) impacts the hydroxyl groups on the surface of SBA-15 in two significant ways: firstly, it raises the zero charge point (PZC) of the Ti/SBA-15 support (from 3 to ca. 4.5), thus facilitating the cobalt precursor-support interaction at a more moderate pH level (pH = 6). Since the pH of the cobalt nitrate solution employed in this work was higher than the PZC of the TiO2/SBA-15 supports, the hydroxyl groups of the support were deprotonated and negatively charged, allowing strong adsorption of Co2+ cations. Secondly, the TiO2 species decorating the support surface have the ability to interact with the isolated SiOx species preventing the formation of the inactive CoSiO4 phase in the CWAO reaction. The effect of the TiO2 loading into the structure of SBA15 by incipient wetness impregnation as well as the physicochemical properties of the oxide Co/xTi/S15 catalysts before and after reaction were studied by variety of techniques. Chemical analysis of the pure xTi/SBA-15 supports showed that the TiO2 content of all materials determined by ICP-AES approached the nominal values, with weight percentages of 1.1, 2.8 and 4.7 % for materials 1Ti/S15, 3Ti/S15 and 5Ti/S15, respectively (Table 1 ). As compared to ICP-AES data, the percentage of phases determined by SEM was a little lower (see Table S1 in Supplementary Information). Compared to the pure xTi/S15 supports, the Co/xTi/S15 catalysts show a slight decrease in TiO2 content. The presence of TiO2 NPs decorating the support surface did not influence the deposition of the cobalt precursor, as deduced from the similar loading of cobalt oxide species (19.4–19.7 wt%) of all catalysts (Table 1). To evaluate the impact of Co species dispersion, we estimated the number of surface active cobalt sites by pulse CO chemisorption. CO uptake is presented in Table 1 expressed as μmolCO/g. As can be seen, CO uptake increases progressively with increasing TiO2 loading. The small-angle X-ray scattering spectra calcined Co/xTi/S15 catalysts show similar patterns corresponding to that of the corresponding support material (Fig. S1 A and S1B of the Supplementary Information). All catalysts show that the three characteristics peaks of hexagonal structure (100), (110) and (200) are preserved, which are associated with the well-ordered hexagonal structure. Evidently, the highly ordered hexagonal structure was well preserved after grafting of SBA-15 substrate with TiO2. However, compared with the pure substrates, the low-angle XRD diffraction patterns of the calcined catalysts (Fig. S1B) show a substantial decrease in the intensity of the reflection peak due to the addition of metal to the supports materials, indicating some reduction of hexagonal long-range periodicity of S15 and xTi/S15 upon the cobalt oxide incorporation. However, the position of the reflection peaks is very similar to that of the corresponding support, suggesting that the mesoporous structure was preserved after incorporation of the cobalt precursor by incipient wet impregnation. N2 physisorption technique was used to study the effect of TiO2 and cobalt species loadings on the textural properties of the synthetized catalysts ( Figure S2 ). Table 1 provides pore structure parameters, including specific area (SBET), main pore diameter (dpore) and cumulative pore volume (Vpore). All supports show a very narrow pore size distribution ( Figure S3 ). As expected, titania deposition on the surface of the SBA-15 substrate resulted in a decrease in specific surface area and cumulative pore volumes. Both values decreased with increasing titanium content following the order: S15 > 1Ti/S15 > 3Ti/S15 > 5Ti/S15. The significant decrease of the specific surface area and the relatively high decrease of the total pore volume suggest that a large amount of TiO2 is localized on the inner surface of the pores. Upon deposition of the cobalt oxide, a substantial reduction in textural properties was observed (Table 1). Among the catalysts studied, the Ti-free catalyst (Co/S15) showed the most significant decrease in surface area compared to its corresponding bare support (S15). The SBET values of the cobalt oxide catalysts follow the order Co/S15 > Co/1Ti/S15 > Co/3Ti/S15 > Co/5Ti/S15. Cobalt species deposition significantly reduces the pore diameter in the Co/S15 sample (by about 0.8 nm). Meanwhile, a smaller decrease of about 0.1–0.3 nm was observed in the titanium-loaded samples. The total pore volume showed a significant reduction after the incorporation of cobalt oxide being this decrease intensified with increasing titanium content. The morphology and structure of calcined SBA-15, Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 were investigated by SEM and TEM. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , the SEM micrographs of all samples exhibit the polydisperse, non-aggregated particles. The sizes of the quasispherical particles ranged from 2 to 5 μm. Noticeably, Co/3Ti/S15 show more open porous structure than TiO2-free Co/S15 catalyst and pure S15 material. On the other hand, the high-resolution TEM image of the pure SBA-15 material shown in Figure S4 revealed a well-ordered hexagonal array of mesopores of the SBA-15 material when the electron beam is parallel to the main axis of the cylindrical pores. Statistical analysis of the particle size shown in Figure S5 of the Supporting Information suggests that the mean crystallite size of the Co/3Ti/S15 is much lower than of Co/S15 catalyst (18.8 vs. 6.4 nm). It is noteworthy that, unlike the catalyst without TiO2, the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst shows a narrow particle size distribution between 4.5 and 8.5 nm, indicating that the presence of TiO2 NPS decorating the support surface influences the dispersion of cobalt oxides. The decrease in particle size observed for Co/3Ti/S15 also suggests the different crystallographic properties of TiO2-containing catalysts. This point was studied by wide angle X-ray diffraction. Fig. 2 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the synthesized catalysts, while Figure S6 in the Supplementary Information shows those of their corresponding pure and TiO2-modified SBA-15 supports. As expected, calcined catalysts exhibit the broad band in the between 20° and 30° 2θ attributed to the amorphous part of the silica oxide, but this band is less prominent due to the coating of the support surface with cobalt oxide. The titanium oxide is partially covered by the cobalt oxide species because only peaks at 2θ 25.28° (101), 48.1° (200) and 55.1° (211) are observed (JCPDS 21–1272). This assumption is derived from the observed decrease in intensity and the disappearance of certain diffractions attributed to the anatase phase. However, it is also observed that the intensity shows a slight increase as the titanium content increases. In addition to the anatase phase of TiO2, the XRD pattern of all calcined catalysts shows the well-developed Bragg diffraction peaks corresponding to the cubic Co3O4 system having polycrystalline nature. The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 19.0, 31.27, 36.85 (strong), 44.8, 59.36 and 65.24° correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400) (511) and (440) reflections, respectively, of the Co3O4 phase with spinel structure (Fd3m space group; JCPDS 42–1467). The intensity and average width of these diffractions maintain a consistent similarity for all catalysts. The average crystal size, which was calculated using the Scherrer equation, was approximately 9.7 ± 0.2 nm. It can be seen that the presence of titanium does not seem to affect the dispersion of cobalt oxide species, as their sizes remain very similar in all samples. For Co/S15, the average crystallite sizes determined by TEM and XRD are very different (18.8 and 9.7 nm, respectively) probably because TEM information is limited to the resolution and field of the microscope and XRD does not detect amorphous phases. The possible influence of the presence of TiO2 NPs decorating the catalyst surface on the metal-support interaction was investigated by temperature programmed reduction of calcined catalysts. Their TPR profiles are presented in Fig. 3 A. As can be seen, the TPR profile of the Ti-free catalyst is remarkably complex, with four distinct reduction peaks observed at 395, 430, 505 and 790 °C. The peak with maximum at 395 °C can be attributed to the reduction of cobalt oxide species [34]. Similarly, the reduction peaks observed at higher temperatures (430 and 505 °C) are also related to the reduction of these phases, but their interaction with the support must be stronger, as deduced from a higher reduction temperature. Finally, the reduction peak at 790 °C is attributed to the reduction of Co2+ species related to the CoSiO4 phase [34]. The reduction peak at 395 °C was also observed in the TPR profiles of all Co/xTi/S15 catalysts. As expected from the similar Co loading, regardless TiO2 loading, all catalysts show similar hydrogen consumption. The peak at 396 °C presents a symmetrical profile and its width appears to decrease slightly with increasing titanium content. This observation implies that the interaction between cobalt species and the support surface may slightly decrease in the presence of TiO2 NPs. Finally, it should be noted that the Co/1T/S15 catalyst shows a substantial reduction of the peak attributed to the reduction of the CoSiO4 phase (790 °C) and that the formation of these species is inhibited in the Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15 catalysts. Thus, modification of the catalyst with TiO2 avoids the loss of active phase due to the formation of this unwanted phase. UV–vis spectra of the pure supports were recorded to obtain more information on the effect of TiO2 incorporation on the structure of SBA-15. The electronic spectra of S15 and xTi/S15 are shown in Figures S7A of the Supplementary Information. The electronic spectra of the pure supports are shown in Fig. S7A (see Supplementary Information). In contrast to SBA-15, the spectra of the TiO2-containing materials show two absorption bands centered around 240 and 330 nm. The presence of the band at 230 nm attributed to tetrahedrally coordinated titanium species suggests that a fraction of the titanium ions is incorporated within the silica structure [35], while the absorption band with maximum at 330 nm is due to the presence of an anatase phase [36]. UV–vis spectra of the calcined catalysts were also recorded to obtain indirect information on the dispersion of the Co3O4 species on the corresponding xTi/S15 supports. Fig. 3B shows the spectra of catalysts after subtracting the spectra of the corresponding support. Hence, the adsorption bands observed at 365, 415, 660, and 750 nm are corresponding to the cobalt species only. The adsorption bands at 365, 415, and 750 nm can be attributed to the octahedral Co2+ species, while the absorption band around 750 nm is typically ascribed to the octahedral Co3+ species [37]. In contrast, the absorption band near 660 nm is attributed to tetrahedral Co2+ species [37]. The population of octahedral Co3+ species shows a slight increase with increasing titanium content, while the population of octahedral and tetrahedral Co2+ species shows a considerable increase with increasing titanium loading. From this it can be deduced that the amount of octahedral Co2+ species exposed on the surface of the samples is higher than that of the tetrahedral species. An additional absorption band, located at 580 nm, observed for the Co/S15 sample suggests the presence of tetrahedral species that may exist on a silica support due to the formation of the CoSiO4 phase [38]. In this compound, Co ions occupy tetrahedral sites of the silica lattice. In fact, this reaction readily occurs at temperatures as low as 350 °C, which is much lower than the calcination temperature of our samples. Since this band disappears in Ti-containing catalysts, it could be deduced that the presence of titanium inhibits the formation of the CoSiO4 phase, which is inactive in the CWAO reaction. The absorption edges (E g) of the catalysts were determined for the band at 400 nm using the Tauc equation. Figure S8 of the Supplementary Information shows the fitting curve of (αhν)1/2 versus hν for the synthetized Co/xTi/S15 catalysts. As can be seen, the E g values follow the trend: Co/1Ti/S15 (5.1 eV) ≈ Co/S15 (4.94) > Co/5Ti/S15 (4.59 eV) > Co/3Ti/S15 (4.1 eV). These values confirm that the dispersion of Co3O4 species is significantly better on the more active Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst, which is in agreement with the TEM results discussed above. The chemical state of the elements in the Co/xTi/S15 catalysts and their surface exposure before and after reaction was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy in the TiO2/SiO2 supported cobalt oxide catalysts. Fig. 4 A show the Co 2p core levels spectra of calcined catalysts, while the binding energies (BE) and surface atomic ratios are listed in Table 2 . All catalysts show the Si 2p peak with a BE value of 103.4 ± 0.1 eV corresponding to Si(IV) ions tetrahedrally coordinated in the SiO2 phase ( Figure S9 ) [39]. As expected, all XPS spectra of the catalysts doped with Ti are composed by two doublets representing the characteristic spin–orbit splitting of 2p level in the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 components. Two doublets are revealed by peak fitting of the Ti 2p3/2 component which shows two contributions ( Figure S10 ): one lower binding energy (∼459.1 eV), usually assigned to Ti(IV) in octahedral coordination in anatase (TiO2) phase, and/or Ti(IV) interacting with adsorbed water or pentacoordinated species [40], and another at high binding energy (460.1 eV), typical of Ti cations having fourfold-coordination with oxide anions of SiO2 [41]. In fact, in conventional bulk titano-silicate (TS), the binding energy for Ti 2p3/2 has been reported to be approximately 460.1 eV [42]. Similarly, the Co 2p3/2 peak of all catalysts exhibit two signals at 780.2 ± 0.1 eV and (781.6 ± 0.2 eV) corresponding to Co3+ and Co2+, respectively, associated with the Co3O4 phase. The presence of these signals is further affirmed by the weak satellite peaks observed at 786.9 eV, which is characteristic of the Co3O4 phase [43] . The intensity of the signal of this phase drastically increases with an increase of Ti content from 1 to 3 wt% being most intense for the Co/3Ti/S15 sample. In addition, both Co/S15 and Co/1Ti/S15 catalysts show the peak at 782.5 eV associated with the Co2+ species of the spinel Co2SiO4 phase. Notably, the formation of the undesired Co2SiO4 phase was suppressed in the catalysts with higher titanium content (Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15). As the titanium content increases, there is decrease of amount of the Ti cations having fourfold-coordination with oxide anions of the silica support suggesting the tendency of phases segregation on the support surface. Consequently, the anatase is the predominant phase in the samples with titanium content higher to 1 wt%. In an effort to understand the impact of titanium on surface oxygen defects, we assessed the Co2+/Co3+ ratio, which was calculated from the areas of the peaks (Table 3 ). Notably, the highest Co2+/Co3+ intensity ratio was observed in the Co/3Ti/S15 sample, signifying a greater presence of surface oxygen defects in this particular sample. The following order was observed in the Co2+/Co3+ intensity ratio: Co/3Ti/S15 (0.88) > Co/S15 (0.75) > Co/1Ti/S15 (0.61) = Co/5Ti/S15 (0.61). This implies that the titanium addition enhances the generation of surface oxygen defects, often associated with the emergence of oxygen vacancies. The effect of titanium on these surface defects does not increase in a linear fashion with the addition of more titanium. It is worth noting that the formation of the CoSiO4 phase is suppressed by the addition of titanium. Indeed, the occurrence of this phase becomes undetectable when the titanium content surpasses 1 wt%, as clearly observed in the Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15 samples. This insight is consistent with our observations from TPR and DRS UV − Vis results. The dispersion of Ti ions on the surface, considered as Ti/Si, as expected was increase linearly with an increase of Ti from 1 to 5 wt%. The dispersion of cobalt species on the surface increases dramatically with the presence of titanium, peaking in the Co/3Ti/S15 sample (Table 2). However, as the titanium content continued to rise, the dispersion declined, albeit remaining higher than of the sample with the lowest titanium content (Co/1Ti/S15). Therefore, one might to conclude that the incorporation of titanium induces several notable effects on the type of phases formed and electronic states of the supported cobalt catalysts. Specifically, titanium suppresses the formation of the inactive CoSiO4 phase, amplifies the formation of surface defects. Titanium oxide is characterized by the presence of surface OH groups with medium-strong acidity, predominantly Lewis type. Therefore, decorating the surface of the SBA-15 support with TiO2 NPs increases the concentration of Lewis acid sites. To examine the type of surface acidity of the calcined catalysts before and after reaction, pyridine adsorption was performed. Fig. 4B shows the FT-IR spectra of the adsorbed pyridine of all calcined catalysts, recorded in the range 1400–1650 cm−1, while Table 3 presents the amounts of their Lewis and Brønsted acid sites calculated utilizing quantitative analysis of the FT-IR spectra. The amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were determined from the integrated areas of the bands at ca. 1545 and 1450 cm−1, respectively, using the extinction coefficients reported by Emeis [27]. All catalysts present similar spectra, featuring five adsorption bands at 1445, 1492, 1543, 1596, and 1616 cm−1. The high intensity band at 1445 cm−1 and lower intensity bands at 1543 and 1616 cm−1 can be attributed to pyridine adsorbed on Lewis sites and Brønsted sites, respectively [27,44] . The band at 1492 cm−1 can be associated with pyridine adsorbed on both Lewis and Brønsted sites, while the band observed at 1596 cm−1 is associated with hydrogen bonded, chemisorbed pyridine [27,44]. As can be seen in Fig. 4B, the Co/S15 catalyst presents the lowest total acidity relative to the other samples. In particular, it presented a lower intensity for the absorption band associated with Lewis acid sites and the highest intensity for the band linked to Brønsted acid sites compared to the rest of the samples. The total acidity increased with titanium incorporation, with a gradual increase being observed corresponding to the increase in titanium content. The Lewis acidity type showed a gradual increase with increasing titanium content. Thus, it can be concluded that Lewis acid sites were generated due to the presence of TiO2 in SBA-15 support. In contrast to Lewis acidity, Brønsted acidity decreased up to the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst, maintaining a very similar value even with a catalyst of higher titanium content (Co/5Ti/S15). The influence of titanium on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites can be more accurately assessed using the ratio between Lewis and Brønsted acid sites (L/B). The L/B ratio follows the trend Co/5Ti/S15 (3.28) > Co/3Ti/S15 (2.79) > Co/1Ti/S15 (2.22) > Co/S15 (1.71), suggesting that the presence of titanium favors the formation of Lewis acid sites, while suppressing the formation of Brønsted acid sites. 3.2 Catalytic activity The effect of SBA-15 support decoration with TiO2 NPs on the activity and selectivity of supported Co3O4 catalytic systems was evaluated in the liquid phase CWAO of phenol. The reaction was carried out in a batch reactor at 160 °C and 10 bar of pressure using air as oxidant. Fig. 5 A and 5B display the phenol conversion and the total organic carbon (TOC) concentration, respectively, as a function of reaction time. As can be seen, the behavior of two Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15 catalysts is different from that of Co/S15 and Co/1Ti/S15 counterparts. The support doping with 1 wt% of TiO2 was not effective because the phenol conversion on both Co/S15 and Co/1Ti/S15 catalysts was similar (about 62 %) (Fig. 5A). An increase of TiO2 loading from 1 to 3 wt% led to an increase of the catalyst activity. However, further increase of TiO2 loading from 3 to 5 wt% did not enhance the catalyst behavior because Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15 show similar induction periods in the first 1.5 h of the reaction and quite similar phenol conversion after 3 h of reaction time (around 79 %). The conversion was not complete probably due to combined factors of equilibrium limitations, catalyst deactivation with time and/or mass transfer constraints, as well as probably problems related to oxygen activation. The conversion of total organic compounds (TOC) (Fig. 5B) was lower than that of total phenol conversion (Fig. 5A), indicating that phenol was not fully converted to CO2, but was transformed into other organic by-products during the oxidation reaction. The total conversion of organic compounds was enhanced by the incorporation of titanium. Comparing the total phenol conversion with that of the TOC values, the performance of the sample with the lowest titanium content Co/1Ti/S15) was significantly superior to the titanium-free sample (C-O) whereas the Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15 catalysts exhibit similar trends for the TOC values up to 80 min of reaction. After this time, the Co/3Ti/S15 sample achieves the highest conversion of organic compounds, reaching 74 % at 180 min of reaction, in contrast to a 67 % conversion of the Co/5Ti/S15 sample. To investigate the impact of TiO2 on the catalyst efficiency toward phenol oxidation, the initial reaction rate was calculated using a pseudo-first-order kinetic model (Table 4 ). For comparison, we included the initial reaction rate of a reference Co/TiO2 catalyst, making sure that its cobalt oxide loading per m2 is similar to that of the Co/5Ti/S15 sample, comparable with a site density between the samples (see footnote in Table 4). As can be seen, the cobalt catalysts on SBA-15 showed a higher reaction rate per catalyst mass than the reference Co/TiO2 catalyst. The initial reaction rate on the Co/xTi/S15 samples increased as a function of TiO2 content, reaching its highest value for the Co/5Ti/S15 sample. However, it is important to note that, when evaluated as a function of catalyst mass, the real impact of TiO2 addition on the density of cobalt active sites may not be fully revealed. The TOF values, which were calculated by normalizing the initial rate with the projected number of surface active cobalt sites, revealed the significant influence of TiO2 content on the catalyst intrisic activity. It is noteworthy that the higher TOF value of the Co/S15 catalyst with respect to the Co/TiO2 reference catalyst indicated the positive role of SBA-15 when the TiO2-modified SBA-15 material was used to support the Co3O4 active phase. Fig. 5C shows the selectivity to CO2, which indicates the degree of complete combustion of organic compounds. The selectivity towards CO2 formation was drastically improved with the addition of titanium. In general, the selectivity towards the formation of CO2 tends to decrease around 60 min of reaction, except for sample Co/1Ti/S15, on this sample there is an increase in the selectivity of CO2 up to around 80 min of reaction time, after this time, the selectivity towards CO2 decreases with respect to the progress of the reaction. Sample Co/3Ti/S15 exhibited the highest selectivity towards CO2 formation and showed the least decrease in CO2 selectivity, with a mere 2 % drop in selectivity to CO2 at 180 min of reaction time compared to initial CO2 selectivity. The Co/5Ti/S15 and Co/1Ti/S15 samples, at 180 min the reaction, exhibited a loss of selectivity of 4 % and 6 % respectively. On the contrary, the titanium-free sample has a drastic decrease in CO2 selectivity, dropping 10 % at 180 min of reaction time. Fig. 5D shows the comparison of the products selectivity at 30 % of phenol conversion during wet air oxidation of phenol (hydroxybenzene) catalyzed by Co3O4. For all catalysts, the degradation trajectory was the same as can be deduced from the formation of the main compounds: hydroquinone (1,4-dihydroxybenzene), catechol (1,2- dihydroxybenzene), p-benzoquinone (1,4-bencenodionas) and o-benzoquinone (1,4-bencenodionas) (Scheme 1 ). The main carboxylic acid intermediates detected by GC were maleic acid, fumaric acid, propionic acid, butyric acid, acrylic acid, oxalic acid, malonic acid, acetic acid and formic acid. Considering the literature reports [7,23,28] and the products detected, the plausible reaction pathway is shown in Scheme 1. The presence of titanium inhibited the formation of polyphenolic compounds. However, this effect was not linear. The lowest production of these compounds was observed in the Co/3Ti/S15 sample, which exhibited the highest selectivity towards the formation of CO2. A higher amount of hydroquinone and p-benzoquinone was observed on the Co/S15 sample, suggesting that these compounds likely contribute to the formation of polyphenols in solution. The concentration of these compounds decreases in the titanium-loaded samples, correlating with a reduction in the formation of polyphenolic compounds. Conversely, the presence of titanium appears to increase the formation of catechol and o-benzoquinone, suggesting that these compounds may facilitate the formation of carboxylic acids, which are intermediate compounds in the process towards complete oxidation. The same trends of phenol and TOC compounds conversions (see Figure S11 in the Supporting Information) demonstrate that adsorption is the primary reaction step, while slower mineralization rates suggest that surface oxidation is the rate determining step of the CWAO reaction over Co3O4 spinel-based catalysts, in good agreement with study by Arena et al. [32]. From a practical point of view, it is necessary to investigate the reusability of the catalysts during consecutive cycles. For this investigation, the Ti-free Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts were chosen to evaluate their stability during three cycles of the phenol removal by CWAO reaction. Each experiment involved using a fresh phenol solution and the catalysts recovered from the previous cycle. Fig. 6 displays the phenol and TOC conversions during CWAO reactions over Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts. The conversion of phenol over the Co/S15 sample significantly decreased after the second and third reaction cycles. There was a 32 % decrease in conversion observed at 180 min of reaction between the first and second cycles, and a loss of up to 52 % in conversion was observed between the first and third cycles. In contrast, the Co/3Ti/S15 sample only showed a 3 % decrease in conversion between the first and second cycles, and up to a 12 % decrease between the first and third reaction cycles. Significant differences were found between the efficiency of both catalysts for TOC conversion (Fig. 6). Decline in the conversion of total organic compounds was found to be more severe for the Co/S15 sample when compared to the phenol conversion on the same sample. At the 180 min of the reaction, the conversion TOC conversion for the Co/S15 sample decreases 51 % from the first to the second cycle, and drops by up to 70 % from the first to the third cycle. For the Co/3Ti/S15 sample, a decrease of 3 % in TOC conversion was observed from the first to the second reaction cycle. A more noticeable loss of TOC conversion, around 14 %, was observed between the first and third reaction cycles. Based on these findings, it can be inferred that the incorporation of titanium not only enhances phenol conversion, but also significantly improves the stability of the catalyst. In Fig. 7 are compared the selectivity of the products at 30 % of phenol conversion over a series of cyclic reaction during the wet air oxidation reactions over Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts. The selectivity towards CO2 formation over the Co/S15 sample significantly decreases with each reaction cycle. Simultaneously, the selectivity towards the intermediate carboxylic acids and polyphenolic compounds increases with each cycle, with a more substantial rise observed for the formation of polyphenolic compounds in solution. This trend becomes more evident when considering selectivities polyphenolic/carboxylic acid ratio. During the first reaction cycle, this ratio was recorded as 0.39, which increased to 0.58 and 0.64 in the second and third reaction cycles, respectively. This suggests that the formation of polymeric compounds in the solution is favored compared to the production of intermediate products, this probably due to major changes in the catalyst. The selectivity towards CO2 formation on the Co/3Ti/S15 sample is higher than the values observed on the titanium-free sample, resulting in a considerably lower selectivity towards carboxylic acids and polyphenolic compounds in comparison with the Co/S15 sample. The CO2 selectivity over the Co/3Ti/S15 sample slightly decreases with each reaction cycle. Concurrently, the selectivity towards carboxylic acids and polyphenolic compounds increases with each cycle, with a more pronounced rise observed for the formation of carboxylic acids. For this sample, the ratio of polyphenolic to carboxylic acid selectivity’s decreases as a function of the reaction cycles. This ratio was recorded as 0.59, 0.52, and 0.39 for the first, second, and third reaction cycles respectively. This results the potential benefits of incorporating titanium to the catalysts for the CWAO of phenol. The titanium incorporation maintained a higher CO2 selectivity and lower selectivity towards carboxylic acids and polyphenolic compounds. 3.3 Characterization of used catalysts The textural parameters of the spent Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts are presented in Table 5 . The dpore and Vpore values in the spent Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst closely mirror those observed in the freshly calcined sample, with only a slight reduction of approximately 10 m2/g noted in the spent sample. In contrast, the spent titanium-free sample (Co/S15) exhibited a drastic decrease in its textural parameters. For this sample, the SBET value diminished by 115 m2/g, accompanied by reductions of up to 30 % and 37 % for the dpore and Vpore values, respectively. These findings demonstrate a significant influence of titanium on the catalyst stability. The spent Co/3Ti/S15 sample, showed minimal changes in the textural parameters. This suggests that titanium incorporation effectively maintained the stability of the catalyst during repeated reaction cycles. The possible leaching of the active phase during the liquid phase CWAO reaction was evaluated by chemical analysis of the Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts tested in three CWAO reaction cycles (Table 5). Comparison of the TiO2 values of fresh and used catalysts given in Tables 1 and 5, respectively, indicates that their TiO2 content is similar. In contrast, when comparing the cobalt oxide loading between the calcined and spent samples, the cobalt content in the spent Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst decreased by 2.5 %, while the spent Co/S15 showed a remarkable decrease in cobalt loading of 37.6 %. Thus, the used TiO2 containing catalyst showed a significantly lower decrease in cobalt oxide content compared to the TiO2-free catalyst. This finding suggests that the presence of titania enhances the interaction of cobalt species with the surface of the spent catalyst, significantly limiting the leaching of cobalt species under the reaction conditions employed. Wide angle X-ray diffraction patterns of Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 used catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . As can be seen, the XRD pattern of Co/3Ti/S15 used catalyst shows the well-developed Bragg diffraction peaks corresponding to the cubic Co3O4 system having polycrystalline nature. The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 19.0, 31.27, 36.85 (strong), 44.8, 59.36 and 65.24° correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400) (511) and (440) reflections, respectively, of the Co3O4 phase with spinel structure (Fd3m space group; JCPDS 42–1467). As expected, the transformation of the Co3O4 phase under CWAO conditions occur, as deduced from the peak at 2θ of 61.8° corresponding to (220) reflection of CoO phase. The transformation of the Co3O4 to the CoO2 phase under oxygen evolution reaction (OER) conditions was reported by others [33]. Thus, we assume that the actual phase under CWAO conditions could be CoO2 (Co(VI)). Similarly, besides the peaks due to Co3O4 phase, the XRD pattern of the used Co/S15 catalyst exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ of 36.6°, 42.6° and 61.8° corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) lattice planes, respectively, of cubic CoO (JCPDS 75–0533). Thus, in contrast to the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst, the XRD pattern of the used Co/S15 catalyst reveals the phase transformation during the reaction from hexagonal Co3O4 to CoO. By comparing the diffraction peaks of the Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/S15 used catalysts, it was found that the former catalyst had lower peak widths, indicating that this catalyst had a higher particle size. The crystal size calculation by Scherrer equation indicates that the crystal size of Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 was 7.6 and 18.5 nm, respectively. Thus, compared to the calcined catalysts, the Co3O4 phase of Co/S15 not only suffer transformation to CoO phase but also its redispersion occur. In contrast, the Co3O4 crystals of Co/3Ti/S15 sinter during the reaction time. Fig. 9 A shows the Co 2p core levels of the Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts after the third cycle of the CWAO reaction. It's noteworthy that the Co 2p core levels reveal a significant difference in the Co oxidation states between the freshly calcined samples and those that have spent the reaction. As can be seen, the TiO2 containing catalyst presents a higher amount of Co3+ ions than the catalyst without Ti. As Co3+ species has higher ability to activate and supply oxygen than Co2+ species, this might explain the higher activity and stability of the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst with respect to its Ti-free counterpart. The integration of TiO2 seems to be crucial in influencing the ionic states of cobalt, it seems to enhance the stability of the Co3+ species, as demonstrated by its sustained performance over successive cycles. Fig. 9B shows the pyridine adsorption FTIR spectra at 100 °C of the spent Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts, while Table 6 presents their corresponding amounts of Lewis and Brønsted acid site types. After the third reaction cycle, the Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts exhibit similar pyridine adsorption as the freshly calcined catalysts. A decrease in total acidity was observed in the spent samples after the reaction cycles. The Co/S15 and Co/3Ti/S15 catalysts showed a decrease in total acidity of 38 % and 15 %, respectively, indicating the decrease in the concentration of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The Brønsted-type acidity decreases by 24.8 % for the Co/S15 sample and 20 % for the Co/3Ti/S15 sample. In contrast, Lewis-type acidity decreased dramatically in the sample without titanium (approximately 52 %), while the Co/3Ti/S15 sample showed only a 13 % decrease. The spent Co/S15 sample displayed an L/B ratio of 0.6, which is about 30 % less in comparison to the fresh calcined sample (Table 3). On the other hand, the spent Co/3Ti/S15 sample exhibited an L/B ratio value of 2.9, approximately a 7 % higher than that its freshly calcined counterpart. Once again it can be seen that titanium has a beneficial influence on the acid properties of the samples. The loss of acid sites was less pronounced in the presence of titanium, with the most notable aspect being the preservation of the proportion of Lewis acid sites even after multiple reaction cycles, property which is crucial in determining the selectivity and performance of the catalysts. To evaluate the strength of the acid sites, we performed pyridine desorption temperature-dependent FTIR spectra for the Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/S15 samples after the third reaction cycle ( Figure S12 ). Table S3 shows the evolution of their number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites with increasing pyridine adsorption temperature. The band related to hydrogen bonded chemisorbed pyridine showed a marked decrease with increasing pyridine adsorption temperature, disappearing completely after pyridine adsorption at 400 °C ( Figure S12 ). As expected, an increase in temperature led to lower pyridine adsorption on both Brønsted and Lewis-type acid sites, with this decrease being greater for Lewis-type acid sites. Regardless of the pyridine desorption temperature, the L/B acidity ratio of the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst is higher than that of Co/S15, suggesting its higher proportion of Lewis acid sites. However, at the high temperature of 500 °C, the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst shows lower pyridine adsorption on Lewis acid sites than its Co/S15 counterpart, indicating a lower proportion of such acid sites. Therefore, one would expect a high concentration of Lewis acid sites on the surface of the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst, along with a lower potency of these acid sites. The amount of coke formed was determined by TGA/DTA analysis of the spent catalysts carried out in the temperature range of 100 °C to 1100 °C. Before evaluating the amount of coke deposited on the catalysts, the samples were dried at 500 °C under an ultra-high purity argon flow (99.9 %) for 1 h, in order to eliminate any hydrocarbons, permanent gases, and water adsorbed on the surface of the samples. Subsequently, the combustion of the deposited coke was carried out by incrementally heating the samples in a mixture of 20 % oxygen and nitrogen gases. The weight loss and DTA profiles of the spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 (A) and 10(B), respectively. The spent Ti-free sample (Co/S15) exhibits much higher mass loss due to coke combustion (23 %) than the Co/3Ti/S15 (7 %) catalysts. The high coke formation on the surface of the Co/S15 catalyst could explain its high decrease in SBET value (115 m2/g) after the third reaction cycle (Table 5). Information into the type of coke formed on the catalyst surface were obtained through the analysis of the DTA profiles, as shown in Fig. 10(B). The Co/S15 catalyst exhibited intense DTA peaks at 571 and 752 °C, attributed to the combustion of coke, being the coke more graphitic with in-creasing temperature [45,46]. Additionally, a minor peak can be observed around 300 °C on this same sample, which can be associated with the combustion of adsorbed carbon species, known to be precursors to the formation of graphitic coke. The acidity of the catalysts appears to play a critical role in the coke formation. It was observed that the catalysts with greater Lewis acidity (like the Co/3Ti/S15 sample) maintained a higher level of activity throughout the reaction cycles. Furthermore, the presence of titanium in the catalyst (Co/3Ti/S15) not only limited the formation of coke but also influenced its type, hindering the formation of more graphitic (hard) coke which is harder to remove and can lead to catalyst deactivation. 4 Catalyst Activity-Structure correlation The activity test demonstrated the positive effect of titanium incorporation into the SBA-15 substrate on the efficiency of supported cobalt catalysts for phenol removal via catalytic wet oxidation (CWAO). Characterization of the catalyst prior to reaction showed that this is because the presence of small TiO2 NPs decorating the substrate surface has a great impact on the structural, textural and acidic properties of the catalysts, and consequently, on the catalytic performance and selectivity. However, an increase in TiO2 loading from 3 to 5 wt% led to a decrease in the phenol removal efficiency of the catalyst, indicating that the amount of TiO2 should be optimised. This decrease can be explained by considering the possible limitation of mass transfer, in agreement with what has been observed for Ti/SBA-15 systems [47]. Indeed, the characterization of the pure substrates and the calcined catalysts indicates that an increase of the TiO2 loading from 3 to 5 wt% caused the pore plugging effect, as deduced from the decrease of the specific BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter (Table 1). In addition, the CO chemisorption capacity decreased (Table 1) and the XRD patterns in Fig. S6 confirmed the aggregation of TiO2 particles for the 5Ti/S15 substrate. All these factors could affect the contact of phenol with the active phase. Since this occurs despite the TOF of Co/5Ti/S15 (Table 4), it could be deduced that the number of active phases is not an average factor influencing the efficiency of the catalyst for phenol removal by the CWAO reaction. It is well known that the strong adsorption of reactant/product on the catalyst surface can hinder desorption of the products. In this regard, the lower strength of the Lewis acid sites of Co/3Ti/S15 with respect to Co/S15 indicate that this catalyst might have a more suitable adsorption, as confirmed by FTIR of pyridine. The optimized reagent/product adsorption on the surface of the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst may also explain its higher phenol conversion, higher selectivity towards CO2 and a decrease in the production of intermediate compounds compared to the Co/S15 without titanium. This suggests that the maintained proportion of Lewis-type acid sites in the better Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst likely contributes to its higher catalytic activity and selectivity, underscoring the importance of acidity properties on catalyst performance. Because the best Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst showed a higher L/B ratio than the other samples, it is clear that Lewis acidity is an important factor influencing on its activity. However, there are other factors that could contribute to the best catalytic behavior of Co/3Ti/S15 in the CWAO reaction. One of them is the inhibition of the formation of the undesired CoSiO4 phase for both catalysts with high TiO2 content (Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15) while this phase was formed in the catalysts without Ti and Co/1Ti/S15. As a consequence, the formation of a higher amount of active phase occurs. However, the catalyst efficiency in phenol removal was not linear with increasing Ti loading, with the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst showing similar activity to its Co/5Ti/S15 counterpart with higher TiO2 content (2.3 vs. 3.9 wt%). In the case of the Co/5Ti/S15 catalyst with higher titania content, the strong adsorption of phenol molecules on Co3+ sites (from XPS) might explain its lower than expected activity. In addition, the comparison of the energy gap of both Co/3Ti/S15 and Co/5Ti/S15 samples strongly suggests that the high efficiency of catalyst Co/3Ti/S15 towards phenol degradation could be related to its lower E gap among the studied catalysts (Egap of 4.1 eV). Thus, Co/3Ti/S15 is the most optimized catalyst for the CWAO reaction. In this work, we found evidence that deposition of TiO2 on the surface of SBA-15 support can promote the partial reduction of Co3O4 species to CoO species. Therefore, both Co2+ and Co3+ species are coexisting on the surface of catalysts. Due to the presence of appropriate Co2+/Co3+ ion pairs, the activity of O2 molecules to was enhanced due to formation of the reactive oxygen species affecting the activity and selectivity of phenol oxidation reaction [48] . The higher Co2+/Co3+ ratio (from XPS) of fresh Co/3Ti/S15 can be explained by considering the promotion by TiO2 of the partial reduction of Co3O4 species to CoO. The appropriate amount of Co2+/Co3+ ion pairs of this catalyst is useful for the activation of O2 molecules to form reactive oxygen species [49] . Therefore, it can be assumed that, at an operating reaction temperature of 160 °C and 10 bar atmospheric pressure, the active phase of the catalyst could adsorb oxygen from the air and create the surface states. In light of the favourable influence of TiO2 on catalyst stability, particularly observed in the Co/3Ti/S15 sample, which maintained excellent dispersion and electronic state of the Co2+/Co3+ pair even after the third reaction cycle, we considered valid the model proposed by Deng et al. [48]. In this model, it is assumed that oxygen can adsorb onto the surface of Co3O4 in three distinct configurations. The interaction of adsorbed oxygen with phenol should be similar to that proposed for the decomposition of volatile organic compounds using mesoporous Co3O4 catalysts [48]. Similarly, activated carbon supported cobalt catalysts having coexisting CoO and Co3O4 species and suitable Co2+/Co3+ redox ion pairs showed excellent toluene removal by oxidation [49]. The possible reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 11 . Interestingly, the formation of by-products (p-benzoquinone, o-benzoquinone, and others) varied depending on the presence of titanium in the catalysts. The presence of titanium in the catalysts inhibited the formation of polyphenolic compounds, particularly in sample Co/3Ti/S15, and encouraged the formation of intermediate compounds towards complete oxidation. Although the role of TiO2 as a by-product scavenger cannot be excluded, more important are the TiO2-induced changes in the physicochemical properties of the catalyst, which directly influence its catalytic behaviour. Thus, from the structure–activity correlation of the catalyst, the reduction of polymer production in solution as well as the inhibition of the active phase leaching can be explained by considering combined factors of the enhancement of Co3O4 dispersion (from CO chemisorption), the decrease in Co3O4 particle size (from XRD and TEM), the presence of Co2+/Co3+ ion pairs (from XPS) and an increase in Lewis acidity (from FTIR-py). The stability of the catalysts over multiple reaction cycles was another key consideration. Unlike Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst, the titanium-free sample (Co/S15) experienced a significant drop in phenol conversion and TOC conversion over successive reaction cycles. This observation supports the hypothesis that the incorporation of titanium not only enhances the catalytic performance but also significantly improves the stability of the catalyst, making it more suitable for long-term operations. In fact, after 3 reaction cycles, the titanium-loaded Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst showed higher phenol conversion, greater selectivity towards CO2, and a decrease in the production of intermediate compounds compared to the titanium-free Co/S15 sample. It is proposed that the deactivation of the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst could be associated with partial reduction of Co3O4 species to CoO species (from XPS), which cannot be efficiently reoxidized to Co3O4 due to limited oxygen mobility. The improved catalytic performance in the Co/3Ti/S15 sample could be related to the higher stability of its active phases located on the support surface, as confirmed by the minimal leaching of cobalt species after 3 consecutive reaction cycles, as well as being due to the superior hydrothermal properties and acid resistance of SBA-15 compared to other ordered silica materials (e.g. MCM-41). The higher stability of the Co3O4 phases on the surface of the 3Ti/S15 material is due to the higher Ti-induced metal-support interaction deduced from TPR experiments. With regard to support stability, the study of A. Mikolajczak et al. [50] showed that unmodified SBA-15 exhibits hydrothermal stability up to 400 °C, which is superior to the temperature of CWAO reaction (160 °C). This is related to the thicker walls and regular structure of the mesoporous structure of SBA-15. After titania deposition by the post-synthesis method, the improvement of the hydrothermal stability of SBA-15 was observed [50]. The improved of the phenol conversion to CO2 is linked to TiO2-nanoparticles addition, which also induces a decreases the production of p-benzoquinone, which is a precursor to polymeric compounds in solution. Considering the FTIR study of the spent catalysts, the improvement of phenol to CO2 conversion could be related to the increase of Lewis acid sites induced by TiO2, which decreases the production of p-benzoquinone, which is a precursor of polymeric compounds in solution. Many reports propose that the dissociative adsorption of phenol on Lewis acid sites leads to the realization of protons that can rest on the adjacent basic site [51,52]. Thus, it should be noted that when phenol is dissociatively adsorbed on the Lewis acid site, the plane of the aromatic ring is tilted toward the catalyst surface. Therefore, when the ring rotates around the axis of the cobalt-phenol oxygen bond, there could be many steric hindrances to the formation of by-products. Thus, it can be hypothesized that in such a situation the formation of methanol should be favored. In addition, Lewis acidity facilitates the ortho-oxidation of phenol by favoring the formation of hydroxyls [22,50,53]. As a consequence of the formation of o-benzoquinone, the oxidation route of CWAO reaction is favored leading to the production of CO2 and H2O [23]. Interestingly, the formation of by-products (p-benzoquinone, o-benzoquinone and others) varied as a function of the presence of titanium in the catalysts. The presence of TiO2 NPs on the support surface inhibited the formation of carboxylic acids and polyphenolic compounds, especially in the Co/3Ti/S15 sample, and favored the complete oxidation of the intermediate compounds to CO2. The stability of the catalysts over multiple reaction cycles was another key consideration. Unlike the Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst, the sample without titanium (Co/S15) experienced a significant decrease in phenol and TOC conversion over successive reaction cycles. This observation supports the hypothesis that the incorporation of titanium not only improves the catalytic performance, but also significantly improves the stability of the catalyst, making it more suitable for long-term operations. In fact, the titanium-loaded sample Co/3Ti/S15 showed higher phenol conversion, higher selectivity towards CO2 and decreased production of intermediate compounds compared to the sample Co/S15 without titanium. This suggests that the maintained proportion of Lewis-type acid sites in the titanium-loaded catalyst probably contributes to its higher catalytic activity and selectivity, underlining the importance of acidity properties on catalyst performance. In this regard, new insights have been provided for the development of efficient catalysts for the CWAO reaction, allowing the efficient treatment of industrial wastewaters. 5 Conclusions Modification of the SBA-15 substrate by post-synthesis grafting with a small amount of titania (2.3 wt%) improved the removal of phenol from aqueous solution by catalytic wet-air oxidation reaction (CWAO) over supported Co3O4 spinel catalysts. The TiO2-modified catalyst showed improved catalytic activity and stability compared to the Co3O4/SBA-15 catalyst without TiO2. This improvement was due to the combined TiO2-induced factors such as enhanced Co3O4 dispersion, decreased Co3O4 particle size, inhibition of CoSiO4 phase formation, increased Lewis acidity, smaller energy band gap and more active phase with high concentration of Co2+/Co3+ redox ion pairs. Titanium oxide, recognized for its superior conductivity relative to SiO2, helps to reduce the bandgap energy of SBA-15 when used for surface modification. This decrease in band gap energy is due, in part, to its conductivity and also arises from defects in the crystal structure, predominantly related to oxygen vacancies, which potentially result in variations and effects on Co2+/Co3+ redox ion pairs. The rate-controlling step of the CWAO reaction over Co3O4 spinel-based catalysts was the formation of catechol and o-benzoquinone. The production of these products was improved on the catalysts modified with TiO2. The best Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst most active and selective toward CO2 was recycled up to three times without considerable loss of activity. CRediT authorship contribution statement D.Y. López-Chico: . H. coredata.dc:description: The removal of phenol from aqueous industrial effluents by catalytic wet-air oxidation (CWAO) is a challenging process that requires novel catalysts resistant to leaching of the active phases during residence time in a batch reactor. In this sense, this work demonstrated that this can be archived with the catalyst having the spinel phase Co3O4 supported on mesoporous silica SBA-15 doped with an optimized amount of TiO2 (3 wt%). In the phenol CWAO reaction carried out at 160 °C and 10 bar O2, this best Co3O4/TiO2/SBA-15 catalyst showed an increase of phenol conversion from 49.0 % to 68.3 % and of CO2 selectivity from 87 % to 98 %. The extensive catalyst characterization and overall activity results indicated that this was related to the strength and nature of the acid sites and the oxidation states of the cobalt oxide phases. Combined factors influenced the final behaviour of the catalyst, such as its intrinsic activity, dispersion of the active phase, inhibition of CoSiO4 phase formation, high Lewis acidity and the large amount of active Co3O4 spinel phase. The presence of TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) decorating the support surface improved the stability of the catalyst by inhibiting the leaching of cobalt species during the reaction. After three reaction cycles, the most efficient Co/3Ti/S15 catalyst showed high CO2 selectivity (∼92.7 %) and low selectivity towards carboxylic acid (∼5.3 %) and polyphenolic compounds (∼2%). It is proposed that surface oxidation is the rate-determining step in the CWAO reaction over TiO2/SBA-15-supported Co3O4 spinel catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Improved phenol degradation by catalytic wet air oxidation on the Co3O4 spinel catalysts supported on SBA-15 modified with TiO2
